SUBJECT:
Approve Latino College Preparatory Academy Charter Renewal
	 
The Charter Renewal application from Latino College Preparatory Academy has been evaluated to ensure that the Charter School complies with all existing and new California laws and regulations, and it has been assessed on both formative and summative aspects of its educational program.  The financial integrity of the Charter School has also been verified.  Attached for review is the compliance matrix, which demonstrates that the requirements for renewal under Education Code section 47607 have been met.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the application with a five-year renewal and annual report and review as will be required by other charter schools.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.02
	 
TO:                               Board of Trustees
	 
FROM:                          Dan Moser, Superintendent
	 
PREPARED BY:            Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
	 
SUBJECT:                    Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: From East Side
                                    Union High School District to San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT,
                                    AFL-CIO
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO for the 2011-2012 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 
2011-2012 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: total compensation which includes salary and benefits; and reduction of work year.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board adopt the District’s initial proposal to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.03
	 
TO:                               Board of Trustees
	 
FROM:                          Dan Moser, Superintendent
	 
PREPARED BY:            Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
	 
SUBJECT:                    Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: From East Side Union
                                    High School District to East Side Teachers Association
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association for the 2011-2012 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 
2011-2012 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; reduction of work year; increase class size; Special Day Class caseload; reduction in athletic director release time/stipend, and reduction in coaching salaries/positions.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board adopt the District’s initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association.

SUBJECT:
Discussion, Consideration and/or Action regarding Selection/Appointment of Board Audit Committee Members
	 
	 
At the January 21, 2010, Board Meeting a staggered process for the selection of Board Audit Committee members was initiated.  One committee member, plus the alternate were appointed to serve one-year terms, ending January 2011.  The other two community members of the Board Audit Committee serve two-year terms, ending January 2012.  
	 
Through a general posting in the community, interested applicants were solicited to submit their applications.  Two members of the community have submitted their applications for the Boards consideration:
	 
Gustavo Gonzalez
Dan Juchau
	 
Per the Audit Committee Charter, one member may be appointed for a two-year term as a Board Audit Committee member and the second community member may be appointed as the alternate to serve a one-year term.  
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
 RECOMMENDATION:
	It is recommended that the Board of Trustees select/appoint persons to serve on the Board Audit Committee.

items.item_details:
Board Meeting of March 24, 2011
Item:  9.09
	 
	 
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
SENATE CONSTITUTION AMENDMENT 5 (Simitian) (SCA 5)
Resolution #2010/2011-32
	 
	 
WHEREAS, Senate Constitutional Amendment 5 (Simitian), which reduces the two-thirds vote requirement on parcel taxes, will be acted on by the California State Legislature; and 
	 
WHEREAS, reductions in the State general fund revenue have led to reduced school funding, and
	 
WHEREAS, State general fund revenue is unstable and erratic, which results in unprecedented funding levels for school districts and county offices of education; and 
	 
WHEREAS, parcel tax revenue can provide a stable, predictable source of school revenue; and
	 
WHEREAS, passage of SCA 5 will empower local voters to invest in their schools based on the needs of their communities by requiring a  tough, but fair, 55 percent vote to pass local parcel taxes, while protecting taxpayers and homeowners with accountability provisions that will ensure that funds generated from parcel taxes are not wasted or mismanaged; and
	 
WHEREAS, revenue from parcel taxes can be spent according to local priorities and are not subject to State control; and
	 
WHEREAS, the two-thirds vote requirement results in minority rule by requiring two "yes" votes to cancel out one "no" vote; and
	 
WHEREAS, passage of SCA 5 will allow local voters to decide to make investments in their neighborhood schools in addition to State funding; and;
	 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District strongly urges the California State Legislature to support and adopt SCA 5. 
	 
PASSED AND ADOPTED this 24th day of March, 2011, by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its Regular Meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California.
	AYES: ________
	NOES: ________
	ABSENT: ______
	ABSTAIN: ______
	I certify the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on March 24, 2011.
	_________________________
	Clerk
	ESUHSD Board of Trustees

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.01
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Hardy Childers, Interim Associate Superintendent of Business Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2010/2011-33 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of Taxable General Obligation Bonds, 2008 Election, Series C (Direct-Pay) Qualified School Construction Bonds in the Principal Amount Not to Exceed $25,000,000
		 
At the September 16, 2010, Board meeting the Board approved resolution 2010/2011-10 authorizing filing an application for Qualified School Construction Bond (QSCB) Allocation for the district.  East Side Union High School District has recently received an allocation to issue up to $25 million in General Obligation bonds, from the February 2008 election authorization, as federally subsidized bonds.  This federal subsidy is a part of the 2009 Federal stimulus bill designed to stimulate the economy and create jobs.  The benefits of this federal subsidy can be transferred to the District essentially providing additional bond proceeds and without causing taxpayers to pay any more in taxes than they otherwise would have had the District not received a Federal stimulus allocation.  The resolution authorizes the sale of up to $25 million in general obligation bonds from the 2008 authorization to be issued under the Qualified School Construction Bond program.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
		$25,000,000
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
		Measure E
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2010/2011-33 Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of Taxable General Obligation Bonds, 2008 Election, Series C (Direct-Pay) Qualified School Construction Bonds in the Principal Amount Not to Exceed $25,000,000.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.02
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Hardy Childers, Interim Associate Superintendent of Business Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2010/2011-34 Approving Authorization to Enter into Contracts to Accommodate Emergency Remediation District Facilities at Education Center for Health and Safety Reasons
		 
There was a power outage in the Main Distribution Panel at the Education Center on January 5, 2011.  The power outage impacted not just the Education Center, but also all of the District’s school sites.  At the time of the incident, PG&E was notified and determined that the source and repair of the outage was not PG&E’s responsibility but was the District’s.  Because of the impact on the school sites and District operations the Maintenance Department engaged a local private contractor, Cupertino Electric, Inc., to investigate the source of the power outage and to conduct the repairs.  Cupertino Electric committed 168 hours of work to the repair over the course of five days at a total cost of $34,900.94.  The contract was made and the work performed without advertising for, or soliciting, any bids.
		 
Public Contract Code section 20113 authorizes the District, in the case of an emergency and by unanimous vote of the Board of Trustees, and with the approval of the County Superintendent of Schools, to enter into contracts for the performance of labor and the furnishing of materials and supplies for any repairs, alterations, or work of improvements as necessary with regard to the public schools without advertising for or inviting bids.  Administration is requesting that the Board of Trustees approve the attached resolution declaring an emergency and effectively ratify the award of the contract for repairs to Cupertino Electric, Inc.  
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$34,900.90
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Deferred Maintenance
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2010/2011-34 declaring an emergency situation and ratifying the contract with Cupertino Electric, Inc. for the emergency remediation work on the school facilities for health and safety reasons.

SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2010/2011-35 Inter-Fund Temporary Transfers for Cash Flow Purposes
			 
Education Code Section 42603, provides for a district's Governing Board to make temporary transfers from one fund to another for the purpose of meeting payment obligations.  However, these transfers are required to be repaid with the same fiscal year unless the transfer takes place with the final 120 calendar days of the fiscal year.
			 
The attached resolution will give the District the flexibility of temporarily transferring cash from other funds if needed to meet the obligation of the General Fund.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
No increase in District Expenses
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution 2010/2011-35 approving the Inter-Fund Temporary Transfers for cash flow purposes.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  13.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
June Francis Rono, Ph.D., Director of Facilities and Planning, and Mr. Bob Hennessey, San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Approval of the Plan for Technology at San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School
	 
	 
Under Prop 39 San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School is eligible to participate in the District's Bond Measure E proceeds.  Bond funds may only be used to improve District buildings/properties and/or to provide appropriate equipment.  San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School, located at 2650 Berger Road, a non-district property, may use Bond proceeds to purchase equipment.  San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School has identified a severe need for technology to support instruction, students and staff.  San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School will be presenting their plan to remedy this resource and access deficiency.
	 
Eligible funding to date was calculated as such:  1) $130 million in Bond proceeds have been issued for projects, which is 37% of the Bond authorized for projects over the next 2 - 3 years; 2) $740 per ADA is the amount estimated for charter schools over the life of the Bond Measure; 3) San Jose Conservation Corp's realized ADA for 2009-10 is 272 x $740 = $201,280.00 available over the life of the Bond proceeds; 4) $201,280.00 x 37% = $74,473.60 available for SJCC until the next draw of Bond proceeds.
	 
The $740 per ADA is derived by the already established Board authorization for "Technology Equipment" cost allocation under Measure E exclusive of the system-wide network upgrade cost divided by an estimated district-wide student average daily attendance.
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$74,473.60
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended the Board of Trustees approve the base allocation of $740 per one time maximum ADA for high school age District resident students attending charter schools within the District for technology and equipment procurement.  It is also recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School Technology Plan and budgeted amount to proceed with the planning, purchasing and implementing as appropriate.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended the Board of Trustees approve the base allocation of $740 per one time maximum ADA for high school age District resident students attending charter schools within the District for technology and equipment procurement. It is also recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed San Jose Conservation Corps Charter School Technology Plan and budgeted amount to proceed with the planning, purchasing and implementing as appropriate.

SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2010/2011-36 To Use School Facility Program Funding For Construction of a Multi-Purpose Room at Mt. Pleasant High School
	 
	 
	 
Consistent with the District’s goal of pursuing all available funding from the State, the administration continues to seek any available funding from the School Facilities Program administered by the State Allocation Board.  As part of the application submittal requirement, the Board must approve the District Representative to file the new construction grant application with the Office of Public School Construction to seek available State funding for the Multi-Purpose Room at Mt. Pleasant High School.
	 
By assigning pupil grants to the Multi-Purpose Room project fewer grants will be available to the District for the construction of actual classrooms.  Nevertheless the Multi-Purpose Room is needed and are used for educational purposes.  In addition, we will be required to build classrooms with only local funds within five (5) years of the State Allocation Board approval.
	 
The District anticipates receiving a grant amount of approximately $2.5 million for this project once approved by the State Allocation Board (SAB) and funds are available for release from the State.
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$2.5 million in favor of the District
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
State Funding Grant
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended the Board of Trustees adopt this Resolution to allow our District Representative to file the grant application with the Office of Public School Construction.

SUBJECT:
Approve the Request for Additional Facilities of KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter School for the 2011-2012 School Year
	 
	 
Pursuant to Education Code Section 47614 (Proposition 39) and Title 5 of the California Code of Regulations (CCR) Section 11969.1 through 11969.11, KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter School has provided East Side Union High School District with the required annual written request for facilities for the 2011-2012 school year.
	 
KIPP San Jose Collegiate is a District approved charter school and based upon the administration’s review of their request, KIPP San Jose Collegiate meets the requirements for additional facilities.
	 
Currently, KIPP San Jose Collegiate uses twelve (12) relocatable classrooms at Independence High School and they are in need of six (6) additional classrooms for the 2011-2012 school year.
	 
Given the space limitations at Independence High School, the administration is recommending that additional relocatable classrooms be installed adjacent to the existing KIPP relocatable classrooms.  This move allows a “self-contained” space for KIPP’s program and should meet their classroom space requirements for several years to come.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter School will pay a lease amount to East Side Union High School District.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To be determined
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Request for Additional Facilities of KIPP San Jose Collegiate Charter School for the 2011-2012 school year.

SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of February 2011
		 
		 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of February 2011, in response to board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.
